com.analog.lyric.collect

Interface IHeap<E>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable, java.util.Collection<E>, java.lang.Iterable<E>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractHeap, BinaryHeap

    public interface IHeap<E>
extends java.util.Collection<E>, java.lang.Cloneable
    Priority queue supporting dynamically changeable priorities of type double.

    Unlike PriorityQueue, the priorities are stored separately from the elements and ordering is based directly on the double values with no intervening comparator. An element with the lowest value will be at the head of the queue.

    Since:
    0.05

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes

      static interface  IHeap.IEntry<E>
      Interface for IHeap entry.

    • Method Detail

      • clone

        IHeap<E> clone()
        Returns a copy of the queue, cloning all of its entries.

      • changePriority

        boolean changePriority(IHeap.IEntry<E> entry,
                     double priority)
        Change priority of given entry in queue.

        When changing more than half of the priorities in bulk, it may be more efficient to defer reordering.

        Returns:
        false if entry was not in the queue.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if priority is not a number.
        See Also:
        deferOrdering(boolean)

      • containsEntry

        boolean containsEntry(IHeap.IEntry<E> entry)
        True if entry is contained in this queue.

      • deferOrdering

        boolean deferOrdering()
        If true, then operations that might affect the order of the queue will not cause it to be reordered until required by some operation such as peek() or poll(), after which this attribute will automatically be set to false.

        Implementations are not required to implement deferral.

        See Also:
        deferOrdering(boolean), isOrdered()

      • deferOrdering

        boolean deferOrdering(boolean defer)
        Defers or undefers ordering of queue.

        When set to true and the implementation supports it, reordering of the queue will be deferred until the invocation of the first method that requires it, namely one of the peek or poll methods or this method with defer set to false. When supported, this will lead to faster amortized reordering when making bulk changes affecting the majority of the entries in the queue.

        When set to false, the queue will immediately be ordered.

        Returns:
        true if value of attribute was set to specified value. Will always return false if defer is true and implementation does not support deferral.
        See Also:
        deferOrderingForBulkAdd(int), deferOrderingForBulkChange(int)

      • deferOrderingForBulkAdd

        boolean deferOrderingForBulkAdd(int n)
        Defer ordering given n entries to be added to the queue.

        Invokes deferOrdering(boolean) if n is large enough to expect an amortized performance benefit.

        Parameters:
        n - is the number of entries the caller intends to add to the queue.
        Returns:
        true if deferOrdering() was enabled.

      • deferOrderingForBulkChange

        boolean deferOrderingForBulkChange(int n)
        Defer ordering given n entries to change their priorities.

        Invokes deferOrdering(boolean) if n is large enough to expect an amortized performance benefit.

        Parameters:
        n - is the number of entries the caller intends to invoke changePriority(IEntry, double) on.
        Returns:
        true if deferOrdering() was enabled.

      • entryForElement

        @Nullable
IHeap.IEntry<E> entryForElement(@Nullable
                                       java.lang.Object element)
        Return an entry containing given element, not necessarily the one with the lowest priority, or else null.

        Assume O(Collection.size()) time complexity unless implementation documents otherwise.

      • ensureCapacity

        void ensureCapacity(int capacity)
        Ensure that queue has sufficient capacity for the specified number of elements.

        For some implementations, calling this before adding many elements can avoid the cost of incrementally growing the capacity as elements are added.

      • entryIterator

        java.util.Iterator<? extends IHeap.IEntry<E>> entryIterator()
        Returns an iterator over the heap entries not necessarily in heap order.

      • isOrdered

        boolean isOrdered()
        Is queue currently in correct partial order.

        This should only be false if deferOrdering() is true.

      • merge

        boolean merge(IHeap<E> other)
        Destructively merges contents of other heap into this one.

        Removes all elements from other and adds them to this heap. Underlying entries will only be transferred if class of other is compatible with this class (typically meaning it is the same class).

        Returns:
        true if entry objects were transferred.

      • offer

        IHeap.IEntry<E> offer(E element,
                    double priority)
                      throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Adds instance of element to the queue with given priority and returns the entry created for it, which may be used to relatively efficiently remove it or change its priority. Unless the implementation does not support it, the same element may be added multiple times with different priorities.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if priority is not a number.

      • peek

        @Nullable
E peek()
        Returns element that will be returned by poll() without removing it from the queue.

        See Also:
        peekEntry(), poll()

      • peekEntry

        @Nullable
IHeap.IEntry<E> peekEntry()
        Returns entry that will be returned by pollEntry() without removing it from the queue.

        See Also:
        peek(), pollEntry()

      • poll

        @Nullable
E poll()
        Removes element with the lowest priority from the queue.

        See Also:
        pollEntry(), peek()

      • pollEntry

        @Nullable
IHeap.IEntry<E> pollEntry()
        Removes and returns entry with the lowest priority from the queue.

        See Also:
        poll(), peekEntry()

      • removeEntry

        boolean removeEntry(IHeap.IEntry<E> entry)
        Remove given entry from queue.
        Returns:
        false if entry was not contained in the queue.
